channel.title: Electric guitar tuner
channel.description:
Did not enjoy making this one. Mainly built it to find new ways of using booleans more efficiently, but hey, got there in the end, although I did spend 2 hours cleaning up the face structure.
[IMG]http://a.imageshack.us/img843/1834/guitartuner02.png[/img] ^^ old render but I like that one.
[IMG]http://a.imageshack.us/img693/7446/guitartuner06.png[/img]
[IMG]http://a.imageshack.us/img834/3887/guitartuner05.png[/img]
[IMG]http://a.imageshack.us/img30/4909/guitartuner07.png[/img]
Wireframes: Now I know there's some dodgy triangles near where the lead input is on top, but after cleaning up all the faces from all over it before, I just couldn't be bothered to do them. :)
[IMG]http://a.imageshack.us/img688/7633/guitartuner08.png[/img]
[img]http://a.imageshack.us/img13/8258/guitartuner09.png[/img]

item.title: Electric guitar tuner
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=“SomethingToHide, post:20, topic:352151”]I said if you do, be smart about it. Have both models lorez and do some math. If you want a circle hole in your model which will be in the middle of a quad, make it 12 sides. Then, you can add a vertical slice down the model to meet with the top/bottom vertices of the hole, and a horizontal slice across the model to meet up with the side vertices of the hole. You should have 2 vertices left for each quadrant section of the hole. These connect to the nearest corner of the quadrant sections they’re in. You’ll have tris forming this circle.

Just do the math to keep whatever shape as low res as possible while keeping the shape you want, whilst also being able to have an even amount of connections on each side.

Then smooth it in the end.[/quote]Happy birthday man

Read full topic

item.title: Electric guitar tuner
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

I said if you do, be smart about it. Have both models lorez and do some math. If you want a circle hole in your model which will be in the middle of a quad, make it 12 sides. Then, you can add a vertical slice down the model to meet with the top/bottom vertices of the hole, and a horizontal slice across the model to meet up with the side vertices of the hole. You should have 2 vertices left for each quadrant section of the hole. These connect to the nearest corner of the quadrant sections they’re in. You’ll have tris forming this circle.

Just do the math to keep whatever shape as low res as possible while keeping the shape you want, whilst also being able to have an even amount of connections on each side.

Then smooth it in the end.

Read full topic

Yes but it’s a bad habit. Also, why even make ngons and cut into quads when you can just always have quads?

So you’re saying completely get rid of the boolean modifier and never use it again and just use slices and extrusions?

item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Exactly. You’ll learn to work more with n-gons than quads and it’ll fuck you over.

Read full topic

item.title: Electric guitar tuner
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

Really to me they’re fine if you cant see it. It can be a bad habit and its better to practice now because when you get into more complex shapes it can have more consequences.

Read full topic

item.title: Electric guitar tuner
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

But surely n-gons are fine providing that the model is not being animated, or being added into a game?

Read full topic

item.title: Electric guitar tuner
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Don’t practice that. Practice making the holes. You have really bad geometry (n-gons) all over this model.

A good technique is to make the object and place it as if you would make a boolean from it, then goto the original model and use a knife tool to make edge loops leading to it, and then shape them around it. Then you can extrude the polygon and have an indent in that shape.

Or use a boolean with both models pretty low res and retopologize it using the knife tool. Either way it’s a lot of manual cutting and tweaking. But just using a straight up boolean to do the job isn’t a good idea unless you’re working with RenderMan and you’re using rendertime boolean ops and subdivision at rendertime as well.

Read full topic

item.title: Electric guitar tuner
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Yes, yes I should of. :o

item.title: Electric guitar tuner
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Well, here’s the story, originally I got the reference image, and cut out the bits that were already on the model:

I don’t even remember why I didn’t just use that image… but hey, I didn’t, probably cause the lighting was different on the top of the image.

So then, I decided to make the background transparent, and delete all the grey bits with the magic wand:

I then added this onto the top face of the model in 3ds max, and then chose a diffuse colour in the material panel to show behind the transparent bit in the image.
I later found out that whatever I changed the diffuse colour to, it made no different to the material, after having the bitmap added.
So… I decided to add the colour back in with Photoshop, I made the colour I thought was suitable, filled the bg, and then layered it behind the previous layer. And then added a film grain filter to add the noise effect.

I also used the same film grain amount on the sides and back, but for some reason that didn’t show as well on the model:

Obviously when I was ‘magic wanding’ I deleted some of the text, I did try to make more of it visible, but then decided it was nice to have a somewhat faded look.

Read full topic
